_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Tarrant Regional Water District

Richland Chambers Pump Station

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





1.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station is committed to the safety of our workers, the public, and the environment.  The resources invested in the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances demonstrate this commitment.  Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station implements reasonable controls, such as training of personnel and the safe design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to make every effort to prevent the release of hazardous substances but in the event of a release, our trained personnel and local emergency response agencies will respond to control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injuries to the public or the environment.





2.0    Description of Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station and Regulated Substances



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station handles one substance regulated by the Risk Management Plan Rule (RMP Rule) in quantities above the Threshold Quantity.  This substance is:



* Chlorine - stored in a bulk storage above ground tanks and used for disinfection of the water prior to distribution.







3.0    Hazard Assessment

 

The RMP Rule requires Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station to perform a Hazard Assessment of the regulated substances stored and used in the covered processes at the facility.  This Hazard Assessment includes an offsite consequence analysis for the following scenarios:

 

* One worst-case and one alternative release scenario for the toxic substance chlorine for the chlorination process unit at the facility.





Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station completed a Hazard Assessment for the covered pr

ocesses and the results have been appropriately communicated to the local emergency response agencies. The Hazard Assessment has been recently updated to reflect changes in population.





4.0    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The RMP Rule requires that a prevention program be established for Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station chlorination processes.  The following details the prevention program elements at Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station that apply to these processes.



4.1    Safety Information



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operation of Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station processes.  Safety data sheets (SDSs) document the physical and chemical properties of hazardous substances handled at Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station, including the chlorine in the covered process.  The engineering design documents include the operating parameters, the design basis and configuration of the equipment in each covered process, and references to applicable codes and standards.





4.2    Hazard Review



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station performs and periodically updates hazard reviews of the covered processes to help identify and control process hazards.  Checklists are used to guide the hazard review. These checklists include items to help ensure Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station operates and maintains the equipment in a manner consistent with the applicable design specifications, codes, standards,and regulations.



4.3    Operating Procedures



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station develops and maintains operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be performed.  The operating procedures are used to

:



1. train employees and contractors, and

2. serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal and abnormal process conditions.



4.4    Training



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station trains personnel in the operating procedures to help ensure safe and effective performance of their assigned tasks. A record of all training is maintained to help ensure new and refresher training is provided on a timely basis.



4.5    Maintenance



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station properly maintains the equipment in our processes.  Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station maintenance program includes:



1. procedures to safely guide workers in their maintenance tasks,

2. worker training in the maintenance procedures, and

3. inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before equipment fails.



4.6    Compliance Audits



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station performs periodic (at least every three years) audits of covered processes to verify the processes are operating in compliance with the requirements of the RMP Rule.  A compliance audit report is prepared after each audit, and any deficiencies noted by the audit are corrected in a timely manner.





4.7    Incident Investigations



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment.  Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station trains employees to identify and report any and all incidents requiring investigation.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.



4.8    Chemical-specific Prevention Steps



Industry standar

ds are followed at Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station to help ensure safe handling of chlorine.  The vendor supplies chlorine via a Department of Transportation (DOT) approved truck.  The accepted general limit of 80% liquid volume is never exceeded.The process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, Compressed Gas Association, and other applicable codes.  Workers who perform operations involving chlorine receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to the guidelines required by Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station.





5.0    Five Year Accident History



There has been no accidents or incidents that resulted in injuries to employee, the public, or the environment Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station in the past five years.





6.0    Emergency Response Programs



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station has prepared a written emergency response action plan that complies with the RMP Rule, other federal standards and industry guidelines.  This plan has been communicated to the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and local fire department.  Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station periodically conducts emergency drills to test our emergency plan and coordinate these drills with the local fire department.





7.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station continuously attempts to improve the safety of our processes to protect our employees, the public and the environment.  Tarrant Regional Water District Richland Chambers Pump Station incident investigations, employee suggestions and improvements in technology are utilized to update the safety aspects of the processes.
